column9: CHIEF COMPLAINT  Long-standing Iron deficiency anemia.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Ms. Christina Cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who was referred by Diane Nelson for a long- standing IODE 12:1954. Her date of birth is 07/01/54, and her last colonoscopy was performed 5-6 years ago. She was unable to donate blood as she was 13 years old. The doctors have not told us why they think she is anemic. This is not the first time she has been told this. There was a blood work result from 12/20/2019 that revealed a low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit and normal iron labs although ferritin was low. At the time, she denied any other symptoms such as sleep apnea, pacemaker, sleep deprivation, or use oxygen at night. Today she started taking 25 mg of iron by mouth in the morning and evening, 10-12 weeks per month, followed by a recheck with the cbc. Be sure to call us if you have any questions or worsening symptoms. (End of Presentation  The patient tried to give blood around december and they informed her that she had been reported to be insufficiently rich in iron. In summary, the patient reports a history of heavy periods, but states that these periods are no longer frequent and have ended with hysterectomy in 1996. “
column10: CHIEF COMPLAINT  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Ms. cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia in 12-2019, and was unable to donate blood until she had a hysterectomy in 1996.  Today she is seeing christina cooper. Her date of birth is 07/01/1954. The patient has been taking Iron pills twice daily since she was 13 years old. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate, 3 hundred,20 phil- 25 milligrams by mouth and is doing a bowel prep to clean out her bowels. Today her periods are no longer the issue. Of note, she has tried to donating blood, around december 2018, but they have not told her if she needs to give any more iron pills or intravenous iron, or maybe something to help her body store the iron better. This is not the first time her doctors have been frustrated with her for a long time. They have also been stating the patient is anemic for approximately a year and frustratingly want her to have another upper endoscopy and colonoscopopy in order to figure out what's going on and if there is any other symptoms, such as a back pain or dyspnea, sleep apnea, or use oxygen at night.Â
column11: ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  Ms. Christina cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia in 12-2019. She was unable to donate blood due to her hysterectomy.  INSTRUCTIONS  Continue each dose of vitamin C found in orange juice twice daily. Do this for about 8-12 weeks, then recheck to the cbc, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate. Then we will send her to a hematologist for further evaluation. If this is inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered to assess for potential sources of internal bleeding.
column12: ASSESSMENT  • ANGELINA cooper, pleasant 65 year old female diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia in 12-2019. She was unable to donate blood.  PLAN  After reviewing her examination and radiographic findings, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. We discussed that her baseline blood labs were normal, she was stable, and ferritin was low. All questions were answered. I advised her to continue each dose with vitamin c found in orange juice, for the next 8-12 weeks, then recheck to the cbc, iron, ferrite, B12,folate,3, Molecule 2,200 mg by mouth. Additionally, she will start taking ferrous sulfate 3 hundred, 20 phil- 25 mg daily. The vitamin C will help her absorb the iron better. do this for about 8/ 12 weeks and then we can reassess your blood work. If this is inconclusive, capsule endoscopy will be considered.  GIF  INSTRUCTIONS  We will plan for an egd and a colonoscopopy to assess for potential sources of anemic or gi bleed, or alternatively, a Capsule of ironopyopy was considered. Thank you for your understanding and assistance today

column14: RESULTS  X-rays of the abdomen were reviewed, and revealed a low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit and normal iron labs.
column15: PHYSICAL EXAM  Respiratory - Auscultation of Lungs: Normal bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Musculoskeletal - Examination of Abdomen: No tenderness where i'm pressing.

column3:
[doctor] hi wayne how're you today
[patient] i'm doing okay aside from this left shoulder pain that i've been having
[doctor] okay and how long have you had this pain
[patient] about i want to say a few weeks i think it's been about three weeks now
[doctor] okay and do you remember what you were doing when the pain started
[patient] honestly i've been trying to recall if i had any specific injury and i ca n't think of that
[doctor] okay
[patient] of anything the only thing i can think of is that i you know i am active and we've just been doing a lot of work in our basement so if i do n't know if i did something while doing that
[doctor] okay alright tell me have you ever had pain in that shoulder before
[patient] you know i i'm really active and so i i will get some aches and pains here and there but nothing that tylenol ca n't take care of
[doctor] okay good but now are you able to move your arm
[patient] you know i have trouble when i'm trying to reach for something or lift any objects and i do n't even try to reach it for anything over my head because then it'll really hurt
[doctor] okay alright and and now are you having the pain all the time or does it come and go
[patient] the pain is always there and then it gets worse like if i try to put any pressure on it it gets worse so if i'm laying at night if i try to even lay on that shoulder it's unbearable
[doctor] okay and then tell me what have you taken for your pain
[patient] i've been taking two extra strength tylenol every six to eight hours
[doctor] alright and and did that help
[patient] it does take the edge off but i still have some pain
[doctor] okay well i'm sorry to hear that you know you know renovating the basement it can be quite a task and it can take a toll on you
[patient] yeah i mean it's been fun but yeah i think it really did take a toll on me
[doctor] yeah what what are you doing with your basement are you are you doing like a a man cave or
[patient] yeah yeah that's exactly right
[doctor] that is awesome great well that sounds like fun i hope you get to set it up just the way you you would like for your man cave to be so congratulations to you there so tell me have you experienced any kind of numbness in your arms or in your hands
[patient] no no numbness or tingling
[doctor] okay alright so let's just go ahead and do a quick physical exam on you here i did review your vitals everything here looks good now lem me take a look at your shoulder alright now on your left shoulder exam you have limited active and passive range of motion and how does that feel here
[patient] that hurts
[doctor] okay sorry there is tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus but there is no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints you have good hand grips alright and then now on your neurovascular exam of your left arm your capillary refill is less than three seconds and your sensation is intact to light touch alright so what does that all mean well firstly lem me go ahead and take a look at your results of your shoulder x-ray here now i reviewed the results and there are no fractures so that's good so let's go ahead and talk about my assessment and plan here wayne so for your problem of left shoulder pain your symptoms are most likely due to a rotator cuff tendinopathy so this means that you injured the tendons of the muscles that help make up your shoulder muscles so i will be ordering an mri for your left shoulder to be sure that there is nothing else going on with your shoulder okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] now i'm also going to refer you to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and during that time you may also continue to take tylenol now if your symptoms do n't improve we can consider a steroid injection for your shoulder which can provide some relief do you have any questions about your plan at all
[patient] so do you think this pain will ever go away
[doctor] now well many patients are very successful with the physical therapy those will those help strengthen you know they do a lot of strengthening exercises with you to help strengthen you know your muscles so that it's not your movements not always relying on those joints predominantly so we're gon na go ahead and start with that and then see how you do okay
[patient] okay okay
[doctor] alright okay well do you have any other questions for me
[patient] no i think that's it
[doctor] okay well i'm gon na have the nurse check you out and she's also gon na give you some educational materials on the physical therapy and what to expect and and then go ahead and schedule a follow-up visit with me as well after you you do your physical therapy okay
[patient] okay
[doctor] alright well have a good day
[patient] okay you too
[doctor] thanks
[patient] okay bye
column4:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne Taylor is a pleasant 66-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago. He denies any specific injury. The patient states he is active and has been renovating his basement. He reports a history of intermittent aches and pains in his left shoulder. He has difficulty reaching for or lifting any objects. He adds that he avoids reaching overhead secondary to the pain. The patient describes his pain as constant and worsening. He notes his pain is unbearable when lying on his left shoulder at night. He denies any numbness or tingling in the bilateral upper extremities. He has been taking 2 Extra Strength Tylenol every 6 to 8 hours, which provides some relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in the bilateral upper extremities.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds.

NEURO: Normal sensation. Sensation is intact to light touch in the left upper extremity.
MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grip.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and are reviewed today. These reveal there are no fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to his current symptoms. I have explained to him that his symptoms are most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. I recommend obtaining an MRI of the left shoulder to further assess the rotator cuff. I will also refer him to formal physical therapy to strengthen his left shoulder for approximately 6 to 8 weeks. The patient was provided with educational materials regarding expectations related to his physical therapy. He may continue to take Tylenol as needed. If his symptoms do not improve with physical therapy, we will consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder. All questions were answered.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me after he has completed his course of physical therapy.

column9: CHIEF COMPLAINT  Left shoulder pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Mr. Wayne Lewis is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right shoulder and right arm numbness. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any clear cause. He is currently working on renovating his basement. His symptoms have included trouble reaching for something or lifting any objects, and he takes 2 extra strong tylenol every 8 hours. This does provide some relief, but it is not enough to completely eliminate his symptoms. When he is laying at night, he tries to avoid touching his left shoulder, which he describes as unbearable. It has been about three weeks since he began suffering from this pain, although he doesn't remember what he was doing when it began. There is no fracture in the humerus, sternoclavicular, acromcavicular or sternoacromiocavelic joints. However, the patient does experience trouble trying to reach for and lift objects over his head. At night he attempts to use his right hand to support his arm, however he notes that he has trouble with his hand grips as well. They are currently doing a lot of basement work, so he thinks he may have injured his hands while doing some hands-on activities. Neurological: Reports left wrist and upper right extremity pain;  VITALS  Capillary refill: Left arm: 0.3 seconds. Sense of balance: minimal. Painful tingling
column10: CHIEF COMPLAINT  Left shoulder pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Wayne Anderson is a pleasant 53-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for neurovascular exam of the left arm. He has been taking 2 strength tylenol every 6 to 8 hours. The pain is unbearable because it is always there and it gets worse if i try to put any pressure on it. Currently, he is doing a lot of work in our basement, but admits that he has trouble remembering what he was doing when the pain started. There are no fractures so that's good. The patient also reports that she has difficulty reaching for objects or touching objects in her hands. She states she tries to reach for something or lift objects over her head but does not attempt to lay on that shoulder. When presented, the patient rates the physical therapy as effective as it takes the edge off.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Denies numbness or tingling in arms. Neurological: Reports left-arm weakness. VITALS  CURRENT MEDICATIONS  Temperature: 2.2 degrees F.LATIONS
column11: ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Left shoulder pain. - Medical Reasoning: The patient’s symptoms are most likely due to a rotator cuff tendinopathy. He has injured the tendons of the muscles that help make up his left shoulder. During his exam today, I reviewed his vitals, radiographic findings, and x-ray results.  2. Physical therapy is recommended for 6 to 8 weeks. If his symptoms don't improve we can consider a steroid injection for his shoulder which can provide some relief.
column12: ASSESSMENT  Left shoulder pain. - PLAN  After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings, I have determined that her symptoms are most likely due to a rotator cuff tendinopathy. We discussed the nature of the injury. I discussed that it is difficult for her to recall and that she should continue to take tylenol. At this time, she may consider a steroid injection for the left shoulder to provide some relief. INSTRUCTIONS  The patient will follow up with me after she completes her physical therapy.
column13: RESULTS  X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal there are no fractures.
column14: RESULTS  X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal no evidence of any fractures.
column15: PHYSICAL EXAM  Respiratory - Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Musculoskeletal - Examination: No rigidness or tingling in the left shoulder.
column16: PHYSICAL EXAM  NEURO: Normal strength therapy. No numbness or tingling in the arms.  Respiratory - Auscultation of Lungs: Milder Examination of the left shoulder: There is some pain to move the right arm. Good monitoring with the nurse at the outpatient clinic: Regularly 2 extra strength tylenol can't take care of
